journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Mathematical modeling of a generic multi-profile form milling cutter

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Industrial Design, National Institute of Technology, Rourkela, India
2PDPM-Indian Institute of Information Technology, Design & Manufacturing, Jabalpur, India

author-notes.corresp: Mohammed Rajik Khan, Department of Industrial Design, National Institute of Technology, Rourkela 769008, India. Email: khanmr@nitrkl.ac.in

abstract.p: In order to machine multiple sculptured surfaces with reduced machining time and high accuracy of the machined parts, shape design of a customised multi-point rotary cutting tool needs to be evolved. In the present work, a novel design of a generic multi-profile form milling cutter is developed for machining various multiple sculptured surfaces. This article describes in detail the mathematical model to design an accurate three-dimensional geometry of a generic multi-profile form milling cutter. Use of non-uniform rational B-spline curve(s) and sweep surfaces enables to control the shape of cutting flutes of the generic multi-profile form milling cutter. The article also discusses the methodology to develop a variety of cutters lying in the same conceptual family of multi-profile form milling cutter. To physically visualise the cutter and to show one of the downstream applications once a three-dimensional model of the cutter is available, one of the multi-profile form milling cutters is fabricated. The proposed methodology offers an intuitive high-quality mathematical model for a generic family of multi-profile form milling cutters, which is different from the traditional three-dimensional models.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Rotary form tools are increasingly used in machining of ‘difficult-to-machine’ materials and/or for general improvement in the productivity of machining operations. Surfaces for components such as dies, vanes, aircraft, car models, etc. are usually of very complex (free form) shapes. The surfaces are often produced by a 5-axis CNC machine tool using ball-end or face-end cutters. However, in machining of compound sculptured surfaces with convex and concave shapes, the performance of traditional ball-end mills or face-end mills is usually limited in applications. The errors generated during machining these surfaces with ball-end or face-end cutters are unavoidable. Usually, the scallops1,2 generated by the trace of the tool nose in each pass increases the machining time (indirectly) and deteriorates the surface quality of the machined parts. So, in order to machine multiple sculptured surfaces with reduced machining time and high accuracy of the machined parts, shape design of customised multi-point rotary cutting tool needs to be emphasised. There exists many two-dimensional (2D)-based representation schemes and a few 3D-based mathematical modeling schema of cutting tools. But, these models are either not suitable for further technological applications (i.e. they are mainly meant for display purpose) or not precise in terms of detailed definitions of geometry (i.e. are approximate in nature). The need is to develop a comprehensive mathematical model that could take into account the wide variety of tool geometry that would take care of varying machining situations for which the cutter may be used. Moreover, in addition to the development of mathematical models of such novel customised cutters, their accurate 3D models are also highly important for modeling the cutting mechanics and simulation of machining.

Although much of the research is carried out in the development of traditional cutters3–5 the work related to the development of customised (special) cutters still lacks researchers’ attention in spite of the fact that they may be used to generate presently required complex surfaces. This may be due to the varieties in the designs of special cutting tools and the involved geometric complexity. In fact, work related to the design of various special form cutting tools has been reported in the literature by Hsieh and Tsai,6 Wang et al.,7 Radzevich,8 Cheng et al.,9 etc., but information concerning the development of generic mathematical models is scarce for the latter. Hsieh10 has developed mathematical models to analyse the interrelationships among the tool angles, the setting angles and the working angles for single point cutting tools. Very recently, Shi and Liu11 have discussed the actual geometry of the cutting tool involved in machining based on their 3D geometric models. Precise 3D geometric models of special cutters would be immensely beneficial in reducing the number of experiments required for tool design and machinability evaluation.

Recent developments in the field of geometric modeling now provide designers an elegant and precise approach of specifying the geometry of complex-shaped objects.12,13 A method for computer-aided design for machining of sculptured surfaces taking the complex machined surface as the non-uniform rational B-spline (NURBS) surface has been discussed by Barari et al.14 and Yau et al.,15 while Barone16 has discussed the geometric design of involute gears using B-spline curve fitting and sweep surfaces. Hence, NURBS curves are known to effectively describe complicated geometric shapes of cutter flanks and gear tooths. In the present work, a mathematical model of the geometry of generic multi-profile form milling (MPFM) cutter is developed for machining multiple sculptured surfaces. For this, the shapes of cutting flutes of the generic MPFM cutter are generated by sweeping NURBS curves.

The objective here is to provide a unified representation scheme for cutters in terms of NURBS curves and sweep surfaces and to facilitate the design of new customised milling cutters. The proposed methodology is verified while rendering the developed parametric model of the MPFM cutter in any surface/solid modeling software through a cutter design interface evolved by the authors.17 For the demonstration of the technology based on the proposed methodology and the representation scheme, one of the MPFM cutters is developed and manufactured using rapid prototyping technique. The proposed geometric model of generic MPFM cutter is more precise and advantageous than the conventional 3D model as the former can effectively be used for various downstream technical usages

The composition of this study is further organised as follows. The comprehensive description for the geometric design of MPFM cutter is discussed in the following section with formulation of mathematical models for generic flute and core body of the cutter. The later section establishes validation of the suggested procedure while generating various MPFM cutters from the developed generic definition. In ‘Technology demonstration’ section the technology demonstration of the cutter model by fabricating one of the MPFM cutters is illustrated. Finally, the last section presents the concluding remarks.

sec.title: Geometric design of multi-profile form milling cutter
sec.p:
The generic MPFM cutter is a rotary form relieved cutter. Its flutes are customised to develop various complex surfaces during machining of products. Its form could be of disc type or end mill type (Figure 1). The 3D model of the cutter is developed in such a way that NURBS formulation enables shape modifications by changing only a few simple parameters. Using the same generic definition, the cutter can be modeled as parallel, angular, circular crown type or a combination type as per the cutting tooth profiles with respect to tool axis, as shown in Figure 1. Multiple profiles are formed on a single tooth of the cutter. The MPFM cutter is designed with an aim to replace a number of form milling cutters of various radii/forms. Figure 1.
MPFM cutters as per the cutting tooth profiles with respect to tool axis: (a) parallel (straight type), (b) angular (tapered type), (c) circular (crown type), (d) combination type.
MPFM: multi-profile form milling.

The surface geometry of a tooth of the MPFM cutter consists of surface patches formed by sweeping the section profile along the boundary curves. Sweep surface can be 1-rail sweep or 2-rail sweep13 depending upon the fact that the section curve is swept along 1 or 2 boundary curves, respectively. A NURBS representation is used to define the geometry of section profile, which is basically the cutting edge profile of the MPFM cutter. Surface-based geometric model for the rest of the surfaces required for completing the geometry of cutter body is developed separately. Various analytical surfaces are involved to shape design the body of the cutter. The present study formulates the mathematical model for a generic flute. Further, while positioning the tooth properly and aligning on the circumference of the core body of the cutter as per the required number of flutes accomplishes the cutter geometry.

sec.title: Mathematical model of a generic flute
sec.p:
The generic flute of the MPFM cutter is made up of a number of surfaces labeled Σ1,Σ2i,Σ2j+1,Σ2+l+f,Σ3+l+f,Σ4+l+f,Σ5+l+f and is shown in Figure 2. landf are the number of peripheral lands and flank faces of the multiple profile of the generic cutter. Peripheral surfaces are labeled as Σ2i(i∈1 tol) while, flank surfaces as Σ2j+1(j∈1tof). To construct a mathematical model of the sweep surface, a generic composite curve (sectional curve) is swept along the boundary curves (rails) lying on a plane perpendicular to the plane containing the composite sectional curve. The composite sectional curve for the generic tooth is represented using NURBS curve. Figure 2.
Modeling of a generic tooth of the MPFM cutter.
MPFM: multi-profile form milling.

sec.title: Sectional geometry of cutter flute
sec.p:
For the convenience of modeling, a reference frame C1{O1: X1, Y1, Z1} is taken at midway along the lateral surface of one of the tooth surface lying on Z1X1 plane. Figure 3 shows the composite sectional curve (V0,…,Vi) lying on Z1X1 plane with their control polygons (V0,B1,B2,B3,V1,…,Vi-1,B3i-2,B3i-1,B3i,Vi), where i is the total number of surface patches required for peripheral lands and flank surfaces of the generic cutter. Here, the composite sectional curve is a tip-to-tip curve on the outer circle diameter of the cutter at one end to the corresponding point on the outer circle diameter at the other end along the axial plane. To make the cutter definition generic, the composite sectional curve (V0,…,Vi) is represented as a composite NURBS curve with i(=l+f) NURBS segment. Segments V2m-2V2m-1 (m=1tol) and V2n-1V2n (n=1tof) of the composite curve corresponds to curve profiles of l peripheral lands and f flank surfaces respectively and are shown as NURBS curves individually on a 2D projective plane in Figure 3. R and 2θ are the crown radius and the crown angle of the cutter respectively (in case of circular crown type cutter). For straight or tapered type of cutter, L is the length of the cutter. Figure 3.
Composite sectional curve with their control polygons in Z1X1 (axial) plane.

For the generic cutter, the composite sectional curve (V0,…,Vi) could be a combination of circular arcs, straight lines and free form curves represented using NURBS curves. The homogeneous coordinates of these vertices may be evaluated with the help of Figure 3 in terms of various dimensional parameters. Let Dc,DReandDLe be the outer circle diameters at the centre, right and left ends of the cutter respectively. A total of (l+f)·(b-1)+1 vertices (V0,B1,B2,B3,V1,…,Vi-1,B3i-2,B3i-1,B3i,Vi) are required to define the composite NURBS curve (Figure 3). The value of these vertices depends on the required design of the MPFM cutter (straight, tapered, circular or combination type).

sec.title: Parametric representation of the section curve
sec.p: The sectional profile (V0,…,Vi) along the axial plane of a cutter tooth consists of ‘i’ parametric NURBS curves, namely, p1(t)topi(t) in a 2D plane. As already mentioned, these are parametrically represented using ‘b’ number of polygonal control points. The generic definition of the sectional profile in Z1X1 plane in terms of parameter ‘t’ may be represented by (1)pi(t)=[fi1(t) 0 fi3(t) 1], for0≤t≤tmax.
The equations of each NURBS segment are evolved as

Case 2: When b = 3 and order of the curve = 3, then (4)Pi(t)=Vi-1h2i-2(1-t)2+Bih2i-1(1-t)2t+Vih2it2h2i-2(1-t)2+h2i-1(1-t)2t+h2it2, for0≤t≤1 and 1≤i≤(l+f) where Vxi's,…,Bxi's… are the polygonal control points and hxi's are the weights at the corresponding control points.

sec.title: Cross-sectional geometry of cutter flute
sec.p:
To model the cross-sectional geometry of cutter flute, the cutter is positioned in global coordinate system C{O: X, Y, Z} with the axis of rotation of the cutter coinciding with Z-axis and the centre at one end of the cutter lying at the origin of C. Figure 4 shows the composite curve (cross-sectional curve) V0,…,V9 lying on XY plane at one end of the cutter. Here, for cross-sectional profile of one tooth, we prefer bottom-to-bottom curve on the root circle diameter, from one end of the flute of the cutter to the second flute. The composite cross-sectional curve is made up of ten segments with V0V1,V2V3,V4V5and V7V8 as straight lines, V0V3andV9V8 as virtual straight lines, segments V1V2andV5V6V7 as circular arcs of radius rf with centers at c1 and c1' respectively, V0V8 as a circular arc of diameter dre with centre at C and the curve V3V4V9 as per the desired form of the flank or relieving surface. Figure 4.
Composite cross-sectional curve in XY plane.

To model the cross-sectional profile (Figure 4) of a single flute, the required dimensional elements are (i) rake face width (l1), (ii) 3D angles (γ1) and (γ2), (iii) fillet radius (rf(=rrf=rlf)), (iv) outer circle diameter at the end of the cutter (De(=DRe=DLe)), (v) the root circle diameter at one of the cutting end of the cutter (dre) and (vi) number of flutes (N). The position vectors of vertices V0toV9 are satisfied by the following relations: V0=[dre2001]V1=[c1x-rf2-c1y2001]c1=[c1x'cosψ+c1y'sinψ-c1x'sinψ+c1y'cosψ01]c1'=[c1x'c1y'01]V2=[De2-l1cosγ1l1sinγ101] V3=[De2001]V4=[rv4cosφrv4sinφ01]V5=[V5xV5y01]V6=[V6xV6y01]V7=[(c1x-rf2-c1y2)cosψ(c1x-rf2-c1y2)sinψ01]TV8=[dre2cosψdre2sinψ01]V9=[rv9cosψrv9sinψ01] where rv4 and rv9 are the radial distances of vertex V4 and V9 respectively, and it depends on the design of relief surface.

sec.title: Parametric representation of cross-sectional curve
sec.p: The cross-sectional profile (V0,…,V9) of a single tooth at one end of the cutter is composed of ten parametric curve (real/virtual) segments defined in terms of parameter s, from p1(s) to p10(s). The curve segments p1(s), p3(s), p4(s), p6(s), p7(s) and p9(s) are straight lines joining vertices V0V3,V9V8,V7V8,V4V5,V0V1and V2V3 respectively, while, the curve p2(s) is the profile of the relieving surface governed by vertices V3V4V9. The curves p5(s), p8(s) and p10(s) are circular arcs of radii rf,rfanddre/2 respectively between V5V6V7,V1V2andV0V8. The equation of these curve segments are parametrically evolved as (5)p1(s)=[dre2+s(De2-dre2)001] (6)p3(s)=[rv9cosψ+scosψ(dre2-rv9) rv9sinψ+ssinψ(dre2-rv9) 0 1], where 0≤s≤1. (7)p5(s)=[c1x'+rfcossc1y'-rfsins01], whereπ2-(tan-1mv5v4)≤s≤π-(tan-1mv7c'1), mv5v4 and mv7c'1 are the slopes of line segments V5V4 and V7c1' respectively. (8)p6(s)=[rv4cosφ+s(V5x-rv4cosφ) rv4sinφ+s(V5y-rv4sinφ) 0 1], where 0 ≤s≤ 1. (9)p8(s)=[c1x+rfcossc1y-rfsins01], where2π-(tan-1mc1v1)≤s≤(3π2+γ1) and mc1v1 is the slope of line segment c1V1. (10)p9(s)=[De2-l1cosγ1(1-s)l1sinγ1(1-s) 0 1], where 0 ≤s≤ 1. (11)p10(s)=[dre2cossdre2sins01], where(2π-ψ)≤s≤2πandψ=2πN. p4(s) and p7(s) are enveloped by the virtual curves p3(s) and p1(s), respectively.

sec.title: Design of flank or clearance surface
sec.p:
The form of the relief surface of a MPFM cutter should be so chosen that after resharpening, the relief or clearance angle is maintained constant throughout the life of the cutter and the flank profile being traced must be preserved. The other consideration for choosing the form of the relief surface is its ease in manufacturability. Three different profiles can be employed to satisfy the form of the relief surface, namely,
Logarithmic spiral
Archimedean spiral
Other relieving profiles

sec.title: Relieving along logarithmic spiral
sec.p: If the path followed by the relieving surface is such that the angle which the tangent at any point on the curve makes with the normal to the radius vector at that point is always constant, the path is a logarithmic spiral. For a logarithmic spiral path,18 let the relief angle, γ2 be the constant angle between the tangent at any point with the normal to the radius vector at that point on the spiral (Figure 4) and De be the outer circle diameter of the cutter. Hence, when the path of the relieving surface of the MPFM cutter is along the logarithmic spiral, then the curve segment p2(s) is parametrically defined as (12)P2(s)=[De2estanγ2cossDe2estanγ2sins 0 1], where(2π-ψ)≤s≤2πandψ=2πN.

sec.title: Relieving along Archimedean spiral
sec.p: If a straight line rotates uniformly in a plane about any fixed point known as pole and if at the same time, any other point emanating from an initial position moves uniformly along this straight line, then the curve described by this moving point is called Archimedean spiral. For the path of the relieving surface of the MPFM cutter following the Archimedean spiral,18 the relief angle γ2 changes inversely as the radius vector. Here, the curve segment p2(s) is mathematically defined as (13)p2(s)=[C(scoss)C(ssins) 0 1], whereC=Kψ,K=πDeNtanγ2,ψ=2πNand(2π-ψ)≤s≤2π.

sec.title: Other relieving profiles
sec.p: If we replace the constant of the curve C in Archimedean spiral by Cn, where n∈[2,1/2,-1/2,-1], we get other spirals for the path of relieving surface. Often, straight line relief is opted for relieving surface. But, in straight line relieving the form of the cutter may not be maintained within close tolerances.

sec.title: Cutter flute surface patches
sec.p:
As mentioned earlier, a number of surface patches labeled Σ1 toΣ5+l+f shown in Figure 2 comprises a generic cutter flute of the MPFM cutter. These surfaces are listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Surface patches of a generic tooth of the MPFM cutter.
Symbol Surface patch name Symbol Surface patch name
Σ1 Rake face Σ4+l+f,Σ5+l+f Face land (right and left)
Σ2i Peripheral lands (for i∈1tol) Σ2+l+f Back of tooth
Σ2j+1 Major flanks (for j∈1tof) Σ3+l+f Fillet
MPFM: multi-profile form milling.

The surface patches Σ2i(i∈1 tol) andΣ2j+1(j∈1 tof) are modeled as 1-rail sweep surfaces. These surfaces are formed while sweeping the profile curve (V0,…,Vi (fori∈l+f)) lying on Z1X1 plane along a boundary curve (p2(s) between vertices V3V4V9) lying on XY plane. These are mathematically defined as pi(t,s)=pi(t)·[Ts]. Here, [Ts] is the transformation matrix meant for sweeping and is given by Ts=[100001000010De2estanαcossDe2estanαsins01], where(2π-ψ)≤s≤2πandψ=2πN for relieving along logarithmic spiral and Ts=[100001000010C(scoss)C(ssins)01], withC=Kψ,K=πDeNtanγ2, ψ=2πNand(2π-ψ)≤s≤2π for relieving along Archimedean spiral.
The sweeping operation p2i-1(t)·[Ts] models peripheral lands (Σ2i(i∈1 tol)), while, flank surfaces (Σ2j+1(j∈1tof)) are modeled by performing the operations p2i(t).[Ts](i∈1tof).
The end surface (Σ4+l+f) is a linearly lofted surface defined as (14)p4+l+f(u,v)=p10(u)(1-v)+p2(u)v,for0≤u,v≤1.

The limits of the parameter s in parametric curves p10(s) andp2(s) lying on XY plane has to be reparameterised to 0≤u≤1. Hence, P10(u)=[dre2cos(2π-ψ(1-u))dre2sin(2π-ψ(1-u))01]T,for0≤u≤1and for relief along logarithmic spiral, p2(v)=[De2e2π-ψ(1-u)tanγ2cos(2π-ψ(1-u))De2e2π-ψ(1-u)tanγ2sin(2π-ψ(1-u))01],for0≤u≤1andψ=2π/N.

The surface patch Σ5+l+f is formed by translating the surface patch Σ4+l+f by d(5+l+f)3 along Z-axis. The distance d(5+l+f)3=2Rsinθ for circular crown type MPFM cutter and for various other profiles (straight, tapered or combination type), d(5+l+f)3 = length of the cutter. It is mathematically given as (15)P5+l+f(u,v)=P4+l+f(u,v)·[Tz,d(5+l+f)3], where[Tz]=[1 0 0 00 1 0 00 0 1 00 0d(5+l+f)31],for0≤u,v≤1.

The surface patches Σ1,Σ2+l+f and Σ3+l+f are modeled as a 2-rail sweep surface. The general equation of sweep along two boundary curves with one section curve13 is given as follows (16)p(u,v)=f(v)[p(u)-p(0)α(u)-p(1)β(u)].Sweep(η,θ(v))+[α(u)p0(v)-β(u)p1(v)],
for 0≤u,v≤1
wheref(v)=(p0(v)-p1(v))/(p(0)-p(1)): scaling factor
p(u): section curve
p0(v)=[x0(v)y0(v)z0(v)1],
p1(v)=[x1(v)y1(v)z1(v)1]: boundary curves
η,θ(v): intersection angles on section plane and base plane respectively
α(u),β(u): blending functions
Sweep (η,θ(v)) =[Rz,η][Rx,-90][Rz,θ(v)] =[cosηcosθ(v)cosηsinθ(v)-sinη0-sinηcosθ(v)-sinηsinθ(v)-cosη0-sinθ(v)cosθ(v)000001]

The surface patch Σ1 and partial surface patch of Σ3+l+f (joining Σ3+l+f of Nth tooth to (N+1)th tooth) is modeled as a 2-rail sweep surface, while sweeping the composite cross-sectional curve p(u) (composite curve V1V2V3:p8(s) and p9(s)) lying on XY plane along two boundary curves p12(t)and p13(t). Shown in Figure 5 is the typical description of sweep surface patch. p12(t) is the virtual outer crown (circular arc) V0V11 lying in the axial sectional plane Z1X1. p13(t) is the inner crown of the MPFM cutter in axial sectional plane Z1X1 joining the vertex V1 of the cross-sectional profile of the cutter at one end to the corresponding vertices at the middle section and at the opposite end of the cutter. Figure 5.
Description of a sweep surface patch: (a) section view, (b) plan view, (c) 3D view.

So, the surface patch Σ1 and partial surface patch of Σ3+l+f is parametrically defined as (17)p1/3+l+f(u,v)=f(v)[p(u)-p(0)α(u)-p(1)β(u)].Sweep(η,θ(v))+[α(u)p12(v)-β(u)p13(v)], for 0≤u,v≤1, where f(v)=(p12(v)-p13(v))/(p(0)-p(1)) η=0∘;θ(v)=90∘ α(u)=1-3s2+2s3;β(u)=3s2-2s3 Sweep(η,θ(v))=[010000-10-10000001]

Surface patch Σ2+l+f and partial surface patch of Σ3+l+f (joining Σ3+l+f of Nth tooth to (N−1)th tooth) is a 2-rail sweep surface. A similar approach is adopted for these surfaces. The composite cross-sectional curve p(u) (composite curve V4V5V6V7:p6(s) and p5(s)) lies on XY plane along two boundary curves p14(t) andp15(t). p14(t) is the virtual outer crown (circular arc) joining the vertex V4 of the cross-sectional profile of the cutter at one end to the corresponding vertices at the middle section and at the opposite end of the cutter. p15(t) is the inner crown of the MPFM cutter and is formed while rotating the curve p13(t) by angle ψ in anti-clockwise direction about origin O.

sec.title: Shape design of the cutter body
sec.p:
The surfaces of the core cutter body depend upon the type of form milling cutter; (a) end mill type, (b) disc type. For an end mill type cutter, it is quite similar to the body of generic end mill cutter as described in Tandon and Khan.5 In disc type cutter, these surface patches are six in number, identified as (i) right body end surface patch (Σ50), (ii) left body end surface patch (Σ51), (iii) bore surface patch (Σ52) and (iv) three surface patches (Σ53,Σ54andΣ55) making the keyway. Figure 6 shows those analytical surfaces which can be mathematically expressed accordingly. Figure 6.
Surface patches modeling the cutter body.

sec.title: Implementation and validation
sec.p:
As per the formulated mathematical model, a number of form cutters belonging to the family of MPFM cutter can be developed. In this section, a few tools lying in the family of MPFM cutters are generated, to validate our proposed modeling approach. The parameters (3D rotational angles and other dimensional parameters) needed to completely describe these cutters and the relevant data for these parameters to exemplify the methodology is shown in Table 2. The dimensional parameters adopted in this work follow the basic tool design principles. As the primary objective of the modeling is to obtain the valid geometry of the tool meant to achieve the desired cutting surface, the constraints are incorporated in the mathematical model of the cutter developed. Table 2.
Geometric parameters of various MPFM cutters.
Dimensional parameters Value (mm)
Cutter 1 Cutter 2 Cutter 3 Cutter 4 Cutter 5
Outer circle diameter of the cutter at the centre (Dc) 56 80 – 80 –
Outer circle diameter of the cutter at the right end (DRe) 56 63 25 56 23
Outer circle diameter of the cutter at the left end (DLe) 56 63 80 56 74
Root circle diameter at the centre (drc) 40 52.5 – 57 –
Root circle diameter at the right end (dre) 40 41 16 40 16
Root circle diameter at the left end (dle) 40 41 52.5 40 52.5
Bore diameter (d) 25 25 – 27 –
Shank diameter (d) – – 32 – 52 (35)
Fillet radius at the centre (Rf) 1.0 2.0 – 1.6 –
Fillet radius at the right end (rrf) 1.0 1.5 0.6 1.0 0.6
Fillet radius at the left end (rlf) 1.0 1.5 2.0 1.0 1.8
Length of rake face at centre (Lf) 6.8 11.8 – 9.8 –
Length of rake face at the right end (lr1) 6.8 9.5 3.6 7.0 2.7
Length of rake face at the left end (ll1) 6.8 9.5 11.8 7.0 9.0
Width of the cutter (L) 40 50 60 72 60
Dimensional parameters Value
Number of inserts (N) 10 10 10 10 10
Rotational angles Value (degrees)
Radial rake angle (γ1) 3 3 3 3 3
Radial relief angle (α) 5 7 5 7 7
Crowning angle (θ)/Crowning radius – 38/40 mm – – –
MPFM: multi-profile form milling.

To model a customised cutting tool conveniently, a tool designing interface called ‘Customised 3D Cutter (C3C) design’ is figured out. The C3C interface helps in rendering the geometry of the cutter in any surface/solid modeling software to validate the methodology as well as to materialise some down-stream technological applications. The rendered cutters for the parameters given in Table 2 are shown using Figure 6. These cutters are generated through the C3C design tool interface and rendered in CATIA V5 environment. The work does not include any additional data verification system to check the integrity of the model, but it can be incorporated if proper software is developed for a commercial CAD system. Also, the software can be modified to include grinder wheel design to sharpen and manufacture cutting tools.

Cutting edges of the cutters tooth are governed using user dependent control polygonal points of respective NURBS curves. While varying the profiles of the MPFM cutter, form cutters like straight, circular, tapered and combination profiles of MPFM cutters are generated by slightly modifying the generic definition and relevant data for the geometric parameters. Cutter 1, parallel (straight type) MPFM cutter shown in Fig. 6 can be used to generate multiple sculptured surfaces as on wooden or metal artifacts. Cutter 2 (circular type) and cutter 4 (combination type) is used to develop multiple radii fillets/circular arcs in aircraft industries, various automobile parts, leather industries, etc. Cutter 3 (tapered type) can be used to develop multiple radii fillets in intricate shapes of automobile parts. Cutter 5 can be used as a finishing milling tool for turbine blades.

sec.title: Technology demonstration
sec.p:
This section illustrates the advantages of 3D modeling of cutting tools over conventional approach by showcasing one of the possible downstream applications that can be performed, once a 3D model of the cutter is available. Here, the fabrication of one of the MPFM cutter is performed using rapid prototyping (RP) process. For the purpose of physical visualisation and the design verification, the designed tapered type MPFM cutter is manufactured using RP machine. The 3D CAD model of the MPFM cutter (as shown in Figure 7(e)) developed by the proposed methodology is imported in one of the commercial CAD software. The surface model of the cutter is converted into solid model and the .STL file format of the cutter is exported to RP machine. The RP model of the tapered type MPFM cutter shown in Figure 8 is manufactured from Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) RP system (Stratasys 400mc). The RP model is manufactured using Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene (ABS-M30) with soluble support material as SR-30. The shape of this MPFM cutter is designed for finishing turbine blades. Figure 7.
Rendering of MPFM cutters: (a) Cutter 1 (straight type), (b) Cutter 2 (circular type), (c) Cutter 3 (tapered type), (d) Cutter 4 (combination type), (e) Cutter 5 (tapered type).
MPFM: multi-profile form milling.
Figure 8.
Tapered type MPFM cutter fabricated through rapid prototyping process.
MPFM: multi-profile form milling.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This work has presented a 3D-based representation scheme of generic MPFM cutters in terms of NURBS curves and 1-rail, 2-rail sweep surfaces and hence fills a perceived gap in the present literature. This representation scheme enables profiles of tooth surfaces to be interactively controlled by manipulating the parameters of control polygons and sweep trajectories. The implementation of the generic 3D CAD model of the MPFM cutter has been discussed in this work and a variety of cutters lying in the same conceptual family of MPFM cutter are developed. To physically visualise the cutter a tapered type MPFM cutter is fabricated through RP process. The proposed modeling paradigm provides an improved understanding to efficiently generate the complex shape of a variety of special cutting tools. In the future, special cutters belonging to a variety of conceptual families of customised cutter can also be generated.

sec.p: This work received financial support by the Science and Engineering Research Council (SERC) of the Department of Science and Technology (DST) New Delhi, India under project reference No. SR/S3/MERC-0038/2008.
